The aims and objectives of this event are

53.text:
Feedback on national performance of candidates
in the June 2015 series.

58.text:
Information which considers the variation
of candidates' performance on different questions

63.text:
and to explore possible reasons which may
explain this variation.

72.text:
The format of the paper is now well established
and again this paper started with 10 multiple

79.text:
choice questions.
We start by looking at these 10 questions,

84.text: which were generally accessible to all candidates.

87.text:
As expected, most candidates performed well
on most of the multiple choice questions.

92.text:
However most candidates struggled to correctly
identify that the correct size hole that would

98.text:
have to be drilled when cutting an M8 by 1.2mm
thread is 6.8mm.

109.text:
Again the format of question 11a is also very
familiar.

115.text:
Here candidates are either asked to name or
give the use of the pictured tools, components

122.text:
or pieces of equipment.
The vast majority of candidates correctly

127.text:
identified the tape measure, a very common
tool in use in the workshop, and many candidates

132.text:
correctly identified the use of the centre
punch.

137.text:
However, the hole saw was not recognized by
many candidates and the block plane was poorly

142.text:
done. A good number of candidates were able
to identify the tool as a plane but they needed

149.text:
to be more specific given there are a number
of planes available to use in a school workshop.

161.text:
We now move on to look at question 11ciii
which was about the advantages of laser cutting.

168.text:
This type of question, a 'Describe' type question,
requires candidates to make a point and then

175.text: to develop it and to give a benefit or consequence.

179.text:
All too often candidates simply respond to
questions such as this with a simple statement,

185.text:
which therefore limits the marks they can
score.

189.text:
An example of this can be seen in the first
example on screen where the candidate simply

195.text:
makes two basic statements and was awarded
a single mark for each of the two statements,

205.text:
In the second example, the candidate makes
a point 'It is accurate' and then they go

210.text:
on to say 'there will be less materials wasted'.
In this response, the candidate scored 4 out

218.text:
of 4 marks for this part of the question.
How candidates performed well in these question

231.text:
Candidates:
Displayed good subject knowledge in the multiple

234.text:
choice questions.
Were able to provide correct material properties.

241.text:
Avoided using generalised vocabulary.
Were able to justify their points.

253.text:
We will now look at a few questions which
candidates generally found difficult.

257.text:
The following slides pick out a few examples
of responses where candidates underperformed

given, 'Durable', was not a correct response

product and then select appropriate properties
of the material given the context, in this

Many candidates struggled to achieve good
marks for this question. Too often candidate

and understanding of the differences between

Question 14b.

431.text:
This question was asking for candidates to
demonstrate their knowledge and understanding

On the whole it was poorly done, with many

463.text:
How candidates failed to do well in these
questions - a summary.

471.text:
For these questions less successful candidates:
Failed to justify their answers.

478.text:
Displayed poor or weak subject knowledge - particularly
in the areas of materials (Polyethene), the

485.text:
differences between thermoplastics and thermosetting
plastics, and manufacturing processes - laminating.

496.text:
Now we will go on and look at the design question,
question 12. The format of this question is

505.text:
well established and candidates should be
quite familiar with what is required of them.

510.text:
All candidates who attempted this question
were able to gain some marks. Weaker responses

521.text:
The example here shows a very good response
to this question. The two ideas provide technically

526.text:
alternative design solutions to the brief.
The first solution shows two cakes held side

532.text:
by side under a single dome cover. The first
solution scores 7. It does not get a mark

539.text:
for identifying a specific process: they do
mention the machine that can be used to bend

544.text: plastic but it is not specific enough.

547.text:
The second solution shows a cabinet with the
cakes held on shelves behind glass doors.

554.text:
This solution also scores 7 marks. It was
not awarded a mark for the point relating

561.text:
to the removal of crumbs where they simply
state that they can be brushed away.

566.text:
It is worth noting at this point that a statement
which essentially repeats the specification

572.text:
point will NOT be awarded a mark. An example
of this would be where a candidate states

577.text:
that the design has a stable base without
any supporting statements or evidence as to

582.text: how or what indeed makes it stable.

585.text:
It is also worth noting here that the candidate
has written a great deal, most of which could

593.text:
have been simplified, saving both time and
making it clearer and easier to read and mark.

599.text:
The example on this slide shows a mature and
imaginative response to this question. The

606.text:
two ideas provide technically alternative
design solutions to the brief. The first idea

612.text:
uses compartments and clearly satisfies the
requirements of the specification.

617.text:
Although no dimensional information is given,
the detail within the well-drafted sketches

624.text:
clearly shows how the cases would be held,
displayed and removed. This response achieved

631.text:
However, the candidate refers to solid white
'card-board', and as cardboard was excluded

637.text:
in the mark scheme, this mark could have been
lost. Nevertheless, it was decided that the

644.text:
phrase exhibited sufficient subject knowledge
to deserve this mark.

649.text:
In the second idea the cases could be removed
from the side, so the mark for 'removal/replacement'

660.text:
It was also accepted that the design solutions
were sufficiently different to deserve marks

666.text:
for 'stability' and 'ease of assembly'.
This example is another good response which

677.text:
scores 10 marks in total.
This candidate has adopted a useful technique

683.text:
whereby they mark up 8 boxes around their
design in the middle. In each box they make

689.text:
a specific reference to each of the eight
individual specification points.

693.text:
Both solutions show two cakes being held side
by side, so a mark is awarded for idea 1 but

701.text:
not for idea 2, as it is a repeat.
This is an example of a weaker response. Immediately

714.text:
you can see that there is a lack of annotation.
When annotation does appear it makes reference

720.text:
to 'wood' rather than to specific materials.
It is obvious that this response is not going

728.text:
Both graphical solutions are also identical
with cakes held side by side, a tray, a lid

736.text:
which opens and made from wood.
As such, the first design scores some good

741.text:
marks, 5 out of 8, but idea two is essentially
a repeat of the first idea.

754.text: Why candidates did well - a summary:

756.text:
Most candidates found it relatively simple
to pick up some marks for their first idea.

763.text:
They were generally able to attract the first
four marks quite easily.

767.text:
They also found it relatively easy to attract
marks for the 'materials' and a 'process'.

776.text:
Performance could be improved by ensuring
that all specification points are addressed

782.text:
in technically different ways, within each
idea.

786.text:
They could try to write less and maybe print
so it is easier to read.

845.text:
This is a well presented response which has
been drawn well (although there are no marks

851.text:
awarded for quality of drawing) which scores
7 out of 8 for each of the two separate designs.

857.text:
In each case, the mark has been lost for not
identifying how the crumbs would be removed.

864.text:
The hand writing and annotation are clear
and simple and aid the marking process.

871.text:
How candidates did well in this question - a
summary.

879.text:
Let us summarise a few features common to
many higher level responses.

887.text:
Successful candidates:
Produced clear diagrams and made use of supplementary

892.text:
sketches.
Showed their design solutions wherever possible.

897.text:
Used specific technical vocabulary.
Produced a second idea which employed technically

904.text:
different solutions for each of the specification
points.

909.text:
Approached the task in a methodological manner,
ensuring that each specification point was

914.text:
addressed within both ideas.
Annotated each specification point in both

919.text:
ideas.
How candidates failed to do well in this question

930.text:
On this question less successful candidates:
Produced simplistic and/or poorly communicated

941.text:
Used labels to identify design features, rather
than drawing them.

947.text:
Repeated design solutions from their first
idea in their second idea.

952.text:
Failed to address some specification points
altogether.

956.text:
Failed to identify specific and/or appropriate
materials and processes.

967.text:
We will look at an extended writing question
and response. These types of questions are

972.text: marked for QWC - Quality of Written Communication.

976.text:
Take a moment to read the response. Refer
to the mark scheme and decide whether it is

983.text:
a level 1, 2 or 3 response. Pause the presentation
if necessary.

989.text:
It is clear and quite well laid out. However
the content is sparse. Two relevant points

996.text:
are made but they are not justified or expanded.
They make a point about stock control but

1002.text:
nothing else is here in terms of how it might
benefit the retailer. Similarly, they make

1009.text:
a point about not everyone having access to
the internet, which is quite valid, but again

1015.text:
they do not go on to say what the implications
are of this.

1019.text:
There is very little use of technical vocabulary
and subject knowledge is limited.

1027.text:
This response barely satisfies the requirements
for level 1 but they did score 2 marks, just.

1038.text:
Now look at this example. This is more characteristic
of a weak level 2 response.

1046.text:
The candidate makes several relevant points
but does not go on and develop them.

1051.text:
The points relate to remembering what sites
a user visits, helping the consumer to find

1059.text:
the cheapest price, and a disadvantage of
dating adverts being shown.

1062.text:
Although the points are valid, they do not
flow and are not coherent in terms of a balanced

1068.text:
view for both consumers and retailers.
As such, the response just about makes it

1074.text:
into the level 2 descriptor but it only scores
3 marks.

1080.text:
Finally, take a look at this response. This
is a good example of a mature level 3 response.

1092.text:
This candidate exhibits a good level of subject
knowledge, and the argument is detailed and

1098.text:
well organised. Points are expanded effectively
and technical terminology is employed.

1105.text:
The candidate discusses the advantages and
disadvantages for both the consumer and retailer

1111.text:
in good detail, with reasoned points.
This response is definitely a level 3 response

1118.text:
as far as QWC is concerned but because they
have used some technical vocabulary with accuracy

1125.text:
and precision, well punctuated with good spelling,
they can be awarded the full 6 marks.

1133.text:
Why candidates performed well in this type
of question - a summary.

1142.text:
Most candidates:
Were able to provide at least one expanded

1147.text:
point.
Were able to write clearly and legibly.

1152.text:
Understood that a piece of extended writing
was expected.

1159.text:
How candidates performed well in this type
of question - a summary.

1164.text:
Most candidates:
Explored a more limited range of issues in

1168.text:
greater depth.
Expanded arguments through several stages.

1174.text:
Employed technical vocabulary.
Used comparative arguments.

1179.text:
Produced planned and well organised arguments.
Exhibited good subject knowledge.

1187.text:
Finally, here is a summary of the most important
issues:

1193.text:
Cover the whole specification content; questions
can and do come from any part of the specification.

1202.text:
Learn properties of materials and their applications.
Practise producing descriptions of commercial

1209.text:
manufacturing processes.
Practise reproducing diagrams from the textbook.

1217.text:
Avoid generic terminology such as 'cheap',
'strong', 'easy' and 'fast'.

1225.text:
Refer to specific materials rather than material
groups such as 'plastic' or 'wood'.

1232.text:
Use spare space on paper to plan for Q12 and
extended QWC (6 mark) answers.

1240.text:
Read the question and highlight key words/terms.
Practise use of connective words in 'Describe'

1249.text:
and 'Explain' type questions.
Ensure that information given in the question

1254.text:
stem is not repeated in answers.
Make sure that answers are neat and legible

1260.text:
and do not write outside the space provided.
Read feedback for Question 12 and practise

1268.text:
technique using past papers.
Manage time effectively - allocating 1 minute

1274.text:
per question allows 5 minutes to read through
the paper and 5 minutes to check at the end.
